elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1. NARRATION/MONTAGE
BEGIN WITH CREAKS AND GROANS OF STRESSED METAL ON SPACESHIP,
SIMILAR TO 19° CENTURY SAILING SHIP.
CUTLERY BEING POLISHED, ACCOMPANIED BY THE GENTLE WHIRR OF
ARMS EXTENDING AND RETRACTING.
Whilst cleaning silverware, one must not be overzealous. Be mindful that each time a knife, fork or spoon is polished, a little of the surface is removed. Cotton gloves must be worn at all times.
CLINKING CUTLERY AS TABLE IS SET.
The table must then be set. Three forks (dessert, dinner and salad); two knives (dinner and fish, blades pointing inwards); two spoons (soup and teaspoon); and a butter spreader.
The water goblet is placed above each guest’s dinner knife; wine and sherry glasses to the right. Napkins are situated to the left of the forks. Everything must be just so.
EGG BOILING IN WATER.

The days seem longer now. Longer, and filled with a harsh Silence. So I keep busy. Today I am up with the lark. I water the plants, run the diagnostics, and do the dusting, all before breakfast. I cook the Captain’s eggs the way she likes them.
FADE OUT BOILING WATER.
But the Captain doesn’t eat her eggs. Not today.
So I tidy the breakfast things away, and rotate the ship six inches to the left, so I can better chart the Caelum constellation.
BURST OF VACUUM CLEANER.
Then, I vacuum the carpets.
Luncheon is at one o’clock — salmon and turbot terrine, lychee
sorbet, chargrilled fillet of beef and butterscotch cheesecake. I light the candles. And then I wait. Nobody eats it.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 3

At three o’clock I go outside to clean the windows of the observation deck, taking care that my anti-gravity thrusters are in working order. Late afternoon I pass by the driving range, and briefly consider a round of golf with Butterworth, the service robot. But Butterworth is very stupid; it would be no contest. Instead I play chess, against myself.
And now I wait patiently in the dining room, till the candles putter out. The glasses remain untouched, the wine — a lively ‘45 Sangiovese — likewise.
SCRAPED, CLEARED. I clear the dinner service, and do the dishes.

At ten o’clock I dim the lights in the sleeping quarters. But the freshly-laundered bedsheets go undisturbed. No-one sleeps on the HMS Aquitaine tonight. The lights of a thousand galaxies twinkle in the infinite darkness outside. It is very quiet.
Tomorrow, I realise, will be the same. And the day after that. It is a sad state of affairs to be a gentleman’s personal gentleman, when one’s gentleman — or lady - is missing.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 4
SCENE 2. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM — IN FLIGHT
HUM OF CONSOLE ROOM, STEADY WHIRR OF TIME ROTOR. ALARM SOUNDS.
Now that’s unusual...
I don’t think I’ve heard that alarm before. Is it serious?
Oh, no — well, not for us, anyway.
AS THE DOCTOR PRESSES SWITCHES
Perhaps you should turn it down, before it disturbs Teg[an] —
INTERNAL DOOR OPENS, TEGAN ENTERS
What a racket! Come on then, what’s gone wrong this time?
And good morning to you too, Tegan. It’s nothing to do with the TARDIS. It’s a distress signal.
Well, aren’t you going to answer it?
BEEPING
That’s what I’ve been trying to do. (BEAT) No answer.
It could just be an automated signal.
Which wouldn’t preclude an emergency. Only one way to find out.
We’re going to look?
We are. (MORE BEEPING) Just need to lock on to the signal...
STOPS.
Got it.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 5
MATERIALISATION
We're landing?
We’re here. The source of the signal.
That was quick.
And smooth. We didn’t have to grab onto the console for support or anything.
Yes. Well. Let’s see where we are, shall we?
HE PRESSES A SWITCH. SCANNER SCREEN OPENS
Now that is odd.
It’s a jungle!
Doctor, are you sure we’ve landed in the right place?
One hundred per cent.
One hundred??
Ninety-ish, certainly. There, you see - the TARDIS is telling me we’ve landed inside the other ship.
But in a jungle? A jungle inside a spaceship?
It’s a mystery. And I do like a mystery. (OPERATES DOOR CONTROLS) After you...?
WALKS TOWARDS INTERNAL DOOR
You first. I’m going to change into some sensible shoes.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 3. AQUITAINE BOTANICAL GARDENS
RAINFOREST. LOW RUMBLE OF THUNDER IN THE DISTANCE.
CREAKS AND GROANS OF METAL STRESS, AS SHIP IS
BY TIME WINDS. (N.B. THUNDER AND METAL STRESS FX
FREQUENTLY THROUGHOUT ALL OF STORY.) TARDIS DOOR OPENS;
STEPS OUT.
Fascinating. (SHOUTS BACK INSIDE TARDIS) You’1l like this, Nyssa. Tropical, sub-tropical and temperate species all in the one place.
RUSTLING OF SHRUBBERY, WHIRR OF SERVO MOTORS AS ROBOT BUTLER EMERGES AND WALKS TOWARDS THE TARDIS
Hello, Sir.
Oh. Um... Hello.
If Sir would excuse me?
AS HARGREAVES EXTENDS A FEATHER DUSTER FROM HIS ARM.
(HUMMING, DUSTING TARDIS) La la la la-la...
EXITS TARDIS
Doctor... what’s that robot doing?
Dusting the TARDIS, it’d appear.

(STOPS) I wonder: would a beeswax polish produce a more beneficial effect? Nothing brings tired wood to life better than a traditional beeswax polish. I have some in my chest cavity, if Sir would allow...?
Be my guest.
A PANEL ON HARGREAVES’ CHEST SLIDES BACK. WITH A WHIRR
PRODUCES SOME BEESWAX, AND BEGINS TO POLISH.
Oh yes, sir. Look at that. She really does come up a treat.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 7
It does look better.
THE TARDIS ISSUES A GENTLE SHUDDERING, GROANING SOUND
Well — the old girl certainly seems to like it. Carry on —
(BEAT) Um...?
Hargreaves, Sir. I am the ship’s computer. And valet.
Well - carry on, Hargreaves. Good man.
Very good, Sir.
Call me Doctor. This is Nyssa.
DOOR OPENS. TEGAN EXITS
What’s happening? The TARDIS is acting funny.
And this is Tegan.
It’s making... weird noises.
Beeswax, Tegan.
Beeswax?
Yes, beeswax. Who’d have thought? Tegan — this is Hargreaves.
Delighted, Miss. Welcome to the Aquitaine. Some tea, perhaps, while you enjoy our botanical gardens?
Thank you, Hargreaves. Tea would be lovely.
I have Chai, Chamomile, Earl Grey, English breakfast...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 8
That one.
A most excellent choice, Miss. And for Miss T— (BREAKS OFF)
Where has she gone?
She’s wandered off, Hargreaves.
Well, that must be a new record.
(OFF) Doctor? Come and have a look at this!
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 4. BOTANICAL GARDENS, NEAR WINDOW [CONTINUOUS ]
(AND WHIRRING) AS THE DOCTOR, NYSSA AND HARGREAVES EMERGE FROM THE SHRUBBERY... ONTO METAL FLOOR.
(APPROACHING FROM OFF) Ah. I believe Miss Tegan may have located the viewing window.
Got it in one, Metal Mickey. — What is that? Outside?
TAPS ON THE WINDOW. THE OTHERS JOIN HER.
That, Miss, is H.E. zero-four five-zero two-nine five-eight.
A black hole.

This vessel - the HMS Aquitaine - is situated on its outer fringes, in the ergosphere. While our primary mission is to collect atmospheric and botanical samples, we have of late been taking ergospherical readings. It has been an interesting diversion.
It’s.. amazing. Kind of beautiful.
I suppose it is, rather. Wouldn’t want to get too close to it, though. — See that light, top left?
A red giant.
Yes. About to be eaten by the black hole.
Poor red giant.
Gamma Caeli, if I’m not mistaken. (BEAT) Still, we have more pressing matters. — Tell me, Hargreaves: why the distress signal?
It’s my crew, Sir. The crew of the Aquitaine. They disappeared. Seven days ago.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 10
Disappeared? How?
That I cannot say, Sir. I... cannot remember. One moment they were here, the next they were not. Tea for you, sir?
No. Thank you. How many crew were there?
Four, Sir. Captain Maynard, Doctor Akunin, and crewmen Jennings and Savinio. Plus Butterworth and myself.
Who’s Butterworth?
A service robot, Miss, of limited intelligence.
60 YDS DISTANT) (SCREAMS IN PAIN
If there’s no-one else here, then what was that?
Merely one of the voices, Miss.
Voices? You didn’t say anything about voices...?
I do apologise for the oversight, Sir. There are the occasional noises - cries, whispers, screams and so forth — but they have no material presence, so I try to ignore them.
No material... Are you saying this ship is haunted?
Now, Tegan, let’s not jump to conclusions. Just because something sounds like a scream, doesn’t mean -
(50 YDS DISTANT) No... Noooooc00o0oo...!
That was definitely a scream.
Well, yes. In this case, you may be right.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 11
Come on - it came from this direction. (RUNS OFF THROUGH A
Now, don’t just run off, Tegan.
I think we should follow. (FOLLOWS TEGAN)
Or you, Nyssa...!
So impetuous, these young people.
Indeed, Hargreaves.
WITH A SIGH, THE DOCTOR RUNS AFTER THEM
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 5. CORRIDOR BETA 17, BOTANICAL ZONE
RUNS AROUND THE CORNER INTO A WIDE BUT OVERGROWN
CORRIDOR, FOLLOWED BY NYSSA
It came from down here. I think.
I thought so too.
But there’s no-one around. (CALLING) Hello? Is there anyone
there? BEAT. THE DOCTOR ARRIVES
Apparently not.
There could be anything hiding in this jungle.
Yes, it is running wild rather. I’m surprised Hargreaves has let it get to this state - seems a fastidious sort of chap.
FOLIAGE AS A DROID EMERGES FROM THE UNDERGROWTH, THIS
ROLLING ON CATERPILLAR TRACKS
You called, sir?
Another robot!
Hello there. And who might you be?
Hargreaves, Sir.
But we've just met Hargreaves.
I am the same Hargreaves that you met
But you don’t look anything like him. wears a sort of... bowler hat?
before, Miss.
Hargreaves is tall and
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 13
I inhabit all the droids on the Aquitaine, Miss. To all intents and purposes, I am the Aquitaine. This particular unit is the ship’s horticultural droid.
Gardener as well as butler? They get their money’s worth out of you.
I perform every function necessary to ensure both the safe running of the Aquitaine and the comfort of its crew.

And I’m sure you do it excellently. I mean, you could possibly prune these shrubs back a little more, but let’s not quibble. (BEAT) Hargreaves, we thought we heard a scream come from somewhere around here. I don’t suppose you heard anything, did you?
I did, Sir. A sound very much resembling a scream came from a point four metres to your right, to be precise.
But there’s no-one there!
I think we’ve established that...
As I said, Sir. The cries, the whispers, the screams — they are all non-corporeal. I cannot provide an explanation.
What is this place? Are we still in the botanical gardens?
No, Miss. This is merely service corridor Beta Seventeen.
A service corridor? It’s more like a garden centre!
Yes, madam. The corridors do seem to have become a trifle overgrown, now that you point it out. It seems that these flora are of the same genus as those in the botanical cultivation centre.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 14
And where is that?
Behind you, madam. Through that doorway.
Doorway? Where?
Behind the large bromeliad, Miss.
That shrub? It must be thirty foot high!
Yes.. Yes, that really should be cut back a little, shouldn’t it? Rest assured, I shall add it to the list.
So these plants in this corridor have spread from the room beyond?
Yes, Sir. They were taken as cuttings from the planet EBT- seventy-seven during our recent visit.
And that was how long ago?
Around three months ago, Sir.
But that’s an extraordinary rate of growth. Almost impossible!
Auntie Vanessa had Japanese knotweed in her garden once, you should see that stuff go.
Hmm. Hargreaves, I wouldn’t mind a look in this cultivation room.
Of course. If you think it will help.
I think I can squeeze... past this thing... Ah!
(FOLLOWING; EFFORT) Right behind you, Doc.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 15
(FROM INSIDE LAB) Goodness, what a mess!
(FROM INSIDE LAB) Nyssa, you coming?
(DISTRACTEDLY) Just a moment, Tegan. — Hargreaves: is that writing?
Where, Madam?
Just there — on the wall, behind that fern. It’s very faint, but I’m sure it’s writing.
Are you referring to the symbols that have been etched into the moss?
Thats right. Le starts “L", “BEB” . then a gape “PRP”, "1" .. 42s that a “G"?
I do believe you’re right. And the final two characters are “B” and “A”.
"L.E. — space — P.I.G. — space — B.A.”. Do you know who might have done such a thing? Or why?
Neither, I’m afraid. I do apologise — it is most unsightly. I shall add it to my list.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 6. CULTIVATION ROOM
LOW RUMBLE OF THUNDER.
Is that... thunder?
More likely the ship being tossed about in the ergosphere. Nothing to worry about.
I wasn’t - (SNEEZES)
Dust allergy?
(SNIFFING) Not usually, no. But this place could really do with a spring clean...
Hargreaves does seem to be letting things slip a bit. Perhaps his mind is on other things.
Didn’t he say there were loads of him, though? Like my Aunt Vanessa always said, many hands make light work.
Oh, I imagine there would be dozens of droids on a ship this Size. But they’re all controlled by a single intelligence. A Single point of failure. Well, potentially.
You think Jeeves has... lost the plot?
I’m keeping an open mind.
So this ship’s from Earth, right?
Or one of the colonies. Your descendants, Tegan. Studying the universe, asking questions. Such an inquisitive species. Some civilizations never leave their home planet, you know.
Yeah. But you know what curiosity did to the cat.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 17
OFF) (YELLS IN PAIN
(ALARM) Nyssa!
THEY RACE OUT, INTO...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 7. CORRIDOR BETA 17, BOTANICAL ZONE [CONTINUOUS]
Madam? May I be of any assistance?
Owww... !
THE DOCTOR AND TEGAN EMERGE FROM THE CULTIVATION ROOM
Nyssa? What is it?
Oh, it’s nothing. Sorry, I didn’t mean to alarm you.
It didn’t sound like nothing.
Why are you holding your arm? Have you hurt yourself?
It was that plant, there - the one with the fronds. Silly of me, really. I leant in for a closer look at that writing on the wall, and it — well, it stabbed me.
It stabbed you?!
There was a spine hidden in the flower. I should have been more careful. These are unknown species after all.
It’s very pretty...
Very. And the way the fronds almost seem to follow you around... it’s quite hypnotic.
Part of its evolutionary advantage, no doubt. Here, let me take a look...
It’s just a small puncture mark. The spine didn’t penetrate very far.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 19
No, but it might have carried any kind of toxin. — Hargreaves, I assume you have medical facilities? Somewhere to clean this up, and check that there’s no chance of infection?
Of course, Sir. My medical counterpart can sterilize the wound and make a full examination.
40 YDS DISTANT) (CRYING OUT IN PAIN
Listen!
Shall I direct Miss Nyssa to the Medical Bay?
If you would, Hargreaves. I think Tegan and I should try and get to the bottom of these screams.
Too right we should.
Very well, sir.
I’1l come with you.
No you won’t. You’1ll go with Jeeves.
Like Tegan said, best be on the safe side.
(CALLING BACK) And don’t touch any more plants!
‘Jeeves’, Miss?
I think that must be an Earth joke, Hargreaves.
Very good, madam.
THEY HEAD OFF, INTO:
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 8. CORRIDOR BETA 20 [CONTINUOUS]
FADE UP. NYSSA WITH HARGREAVES; HARGREAVES HALTS.
This is the perimeter of the Botanical Zone, Miss.
Is it? How can you tell?
I can only apologise once more for the abundant vegetation in the corridors. I really cannot understand how it got here.
Well — it grew, presumably. And very fast.
As you say. Yet I have no memory of it not being here.
That is strange.
I offer no excuse - my horticultural skills are evidently lacking. I am at a complete loss to explain why that might be. It really is very odd. —
HARGREAVES ROLLS IN — ON WHEELS, RATHER THAN TRACKS
Ah! And here is my medical colleague.
(ARRIVING) Good morning, Miss. If you would like to follow me?
But - when you say you can’t explain it...?
If you would follow my colleague, he will examine your wound. Good day, Miss Nyssa. (TRUNDLES AWAY)
What do you mean, ‘odd’? Hargreaves? Hargreaves?
This way, Miss.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 21
SCENE 9. CORRIDOR BETA 10
CRIES IN PAIN
FOOTSTEPS APPROACH. TEGAN ARRIVES, OUT OF BREATH.
Anything... Anything here, this time?
No. No, just another phantom.
A phantom?! You’ve changed your tune!
Have I?
Yeah. When I said this place might be haunted you gave me one of your looks.
‘Phantom’ as in ‘a phenomenon with no material presence’, Tegan — not someone with clanking chains and their head tucked underneath their arm.. (BEAT) What do you mean, one of my ‘looks’?
You know. Half pained, half patronising.
Do I really do that?
I guess Jeeves was right after all — there is no-one else on the ship.
But there’s still the matter of the missing crew — which is, after all, why we’re here. And if these apparitions aren’t somehow connected...
Yes?
Well, it would be an extraordinary coincidence.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 10. SICK BAY
A SWOOSH OF DOORS; HARGREAVES AND NYSSA ENTER
The Aquitaine medical centre. If Miss would take a seat?
Thank you, Hargreaves. Do you have some water?
Certainly, Miss.
SOME WATER
Thank you. It’s so hot in here.
The ambient temperature is regulated at 295 Kelvin - the optimum level for the comfort of humans.
It must be me then. I’m feeling quite... flushed.
Now - if Miss would roll up her sleeve, I will prepare a local anaesthetic.
Of course. (ROLLING BACK SLEEVE) Look — it’s swollen.
I’m sure it’s nothing to worry about, Miss.
I’m sure you’re right.
And if Miss should go into anaphylactic shock, then I have all necessary treatments available.
Very reassuring.
THE SHIP VIBRATES SLIGHTLY
Did you feel that?
Miss?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 23
The whole ship seemed to... tremble.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 11. CORRIDOR BETA 9
DOCTOR AND TEGAN WALKING ALONG METAL FLOOR.
Wait.. did you feel that?
Yes... what was it?
I don’t know. A vibration. A ripple, even.
A ripple in what?
I wouldn’t like to say. Interesting, though.
30 YDS DISTANT) (EERIE SOBBING — CONTINUES UNDER FOLLOWING
Interesting?
Very. Come on. Quietly.
THEY FOLLOW THE SOUND OF THE SOBBING. AFTER A FEW SECONDS THEY TURN A CORNER, AND THE SOBBING STOPS.
(LOUDLY) Hello?
Which part of ‘quietly’...?
ECHO FROM DOWN THE CORRIDOR
Shhhhhhh! — Did you hear that? It sounded like footsteps. From down there, I think.
15 YDS DISTANT) Make it stop. Make it stop. (SOBS
This way.
THEY HURRY TOWARDS THE VOICE
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 25
Ohhhh... Oh, it hurts. It hurts so much. (SOBS) Make it stop... Sergei, please.
AS THE DOCTOR AND TEGAN APPROACH, THE SOBBING DIES AWAY
Nothing. She’s gone.
Did you hear what she was saying?
Yes. Make what stop, I wonder? What happened here?
SOBBING, IN THE FAR DISTANCE.
There it goes again. You still don’t think it’s a ghost?
I don’t believe in ghosts. Not the type you mean, anyway.
What other kinds of ghosts are there?
Ghosts are... interference. Projections of things that have happened, or will happen.
(OFF) Maurizio? Maurizio, where are you?
(GASPS) Look! I saw it this time! All see-through!
A young woman, yes.
Our ghost! Come on!
THE DOCTOR AND TEGAN START RUNNING.
You think she’s one of the missing crew?
Judging from her attire, I’d say that’s highly likely. I wonder
where she’s going?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 26
Round the corner, quick!
THEY TURN A CORNER, AND HALT.
Well — where’s she gone? All that’s here is a lift. Do ghosts even take lifts?
(BEHIND THEM) Oh no... It’s happening again, isn’t it...?
Ah. There she is — behind us, you see?
But that’s where we came from! She’s playing games with us.
I don’t think ghosts play games, either.
She’d better not be. My feet are killing me.
I thought you changed into more sensible shoes?
I wasn’t expecting to do this much running.
(ON PA SYSTEM) Doctor, this is Hargreaves.
Where’s he coming from?
Some kind of ship-wide communications system, I presume. — Yes, Hargreaves?
(ON PA SYSTEM) I’m afraid that there is a.. problem with Miss Nyssa.
What do you mean? What kind of a problem?
(ON PA SYSTEM) It seems that she has... disappeared.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 12. SICK BAY
[NB: ANOTHER TIME ZONE. ]
(COMING TO) Ohhh... my head. What was that? (BEAT) Hargreaves, do you have anything for a headache?
Hargreaves? (SITS UP AND LOOKS AROUND) Hargreaves — where are you? (TO SELF) He’s gone...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 13. SICK BAY
FADE UP ON BEEP OF MEDICAL EQUIPMENT
When you say Nyssa disappeared...
My apologies, Sir. That description was imprecise and possibly misleading.
So you didn’t actually see her vanish into thin air?
No, Sir.
But you didn’t see her leave Sickbay either?
That is also true. I turned my back on Miss Nyssa to prepare an analgesic, and when I turned back she had gone.
So she could have just walked out of the room?
The reason I do not consider that likely, Miss, is that she was not seen to do so by the cameras in the corridor beyond.
Oh. That’s weird.
Do you have a camera in this room?
No, Sir — for reasons of clinical ethics. For privacy reasons there are also no cameras in the bedrooms, the washrooms, the water closets, [the]
(INTERRUPTING) Of course... (BEAT) Can you scan for life signs?
Indeed, Sir. I regret to say that the only life signs on board are those of you and Miss Tegan, in this room.
Then where is she?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 29
I’m quite sure there’s a rational explanation.
I’m not.
Maybe Hargreaves’ sensors are on the blink? — This ship’s seen better days, after all. No offence, Hargreaves.
I would take none even if I were able, Sir.
Let’s retrace our steps. It’s a big ship - maybe she got lost on the way back to us...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 14. CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
WALKS BACK TOWARDS THE BOTANICAL GARDENS.
(SHOUTS) Doctor! Doctor, hello!
BUTLER HARGREAVES TRUNDLES UP BEHIND HER
May I help you, Madam?
Ah! Where did you go?
I’m sorry, I do not understand the question. Go where?
You were with me one minute, and the next...
I regret to say that I have never met you before, Madam.
Not you - the medical droid. I was just with hin...
As I say, Madam - I have never met you before.
Now I really have a headache.
Would you like me to fetch the medical droid, Madam?
No. No, it’s fine. And it’s Nyssa. My name.
A pleasure, Miss Nyssa. Would you like some tea?
No. No, I need to communicate with the botanical gardens. Can you do that?
Of course, Miss Nyssa. The Aquitaine is equipped with an intelligent Intracom system covering the entire ship.
Intracom?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 31
Indeed. Wherever you are, simply speak your instructions out loud and you will be routed to either myself, or to whomever else you choose.
Hello? Doctor? Doctor, can you hear me?
A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
(ON INTERCOM) Nyssa? Where are you?
Oh — thank goodness. I thought — well, I don’t know what I thought. I was all alone.
A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
(ON INTERCOM) Where are you?
I’m walking towards the botanical gardens. Corridor... Gamma 12.
A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
(ON INTERCOM) Stay where you are — we’1ll come to you.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 32
SCENE 15. CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
Nyssa? Nyssa! (BEAT) This is where she said she was, all right.
Hargreaves, can you show us what that security camera is seeing?
Of course, Sir. I will patch its output into my chest display.
BEEP AS HE DOES SO
That’s.. snazzy.
Just us... (BEAT) Nyssa? What are you looking at right now?
A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
(OVER INTERCOM) I’m standing directly under a sign that says ‘Gamma 12’, facing toward the junction. Where are you?
I’m. that’s exactly where we are.
This is weird. Are you sure there aren’t two corridor Gamma twelves?
(SHARPLY) Both of which lead directly from the medical bay to the botanical gardens?
I’m worried too, you know?
Doctor, I have identified something rather unusual.
What’s that, Hargreaves?
I have recalibrated my sensors and am now picking up a very faint life sign. But the signal is slightly adrift from its location. Like an echo.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 33
Doctor - when Nyssa speaks, she sounds like she’s a few seconds out! You know, like when there’s a satellite delay on TV...
Yes, I was wondering about that...
THE LIGHTS FLICKER AND THE SHIP SHAKES
Not again!
Nyssa, did the lights just flicker where you are?
A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
(OVER INTERCOM) Yes, Doctor. And the ship is shaking...
THE SHAKING BECOMES MORE VIOLENT
It’s worse this time. More violent... Tegan, hold on to something.
(SHAKILY) I take back everything I ever said about your driving...
Hargreaves, can you detect any external cause for the disturbance?
Nothing, Sir; though my sensors — my sensors — my...
A DEEP AND CAVERNOUS CRASH, LIKE A DISTANT THUNDERBOLT HITTING THE SHIP
My... my.. (BEAT) I have engaged the emergency lighting, Sir.
Thank you, Hargreaves. (BEAT) Is there something wrong?
Hargreaves?
Now his lights have gone off...
THE SHAKING SUBSIDES
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 34
I think that’s it.. (GETS HIS BREATH BACK) Nyssa, are you all right?
Nyssa? Nyssa!

TEGAN: (GASPS) Look! I saw it this time! All see-through!
DOCTOR: A young woman, yes.
TEGAN: Our ghost! Come on!
TEGAN: THE DOCTOR AND TEGAN START RUNNING.
TEGAN: You think she’s one of the missing crew?
DOCTOR: Judging from her attire, I’d say that’s highly likely. I wonder
DOCTOR: where she’s going?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 26
TEGAN: Round the corner, quick!
TEGAN: THEY TURN A CORNER, AND HALT.
TEGAN: Well — where’s she gone? All that’s here is a lift. Do ghosts even take lifts?
FREYA: (BEHIND THEM) Oh no... It’s happening again, isn’t it...?
DOCTOR: Ah. There she is — behind us, you see?
TEGAN: But that’s where we came from! She’s playing games with us.
DOCTOR: I don’t think ghosts play games, either.
TEGAN: She’d better not be. My feet are killing me.
DOCTOR: I thought you changed into more sensible shoes?
TEGAN: I wasn’t expecting to do this much running.
SHIP HARGREAVES: (ON PA SYSTEM) Doctor, this is Hargreaves.
TEGAN: Where’s he coming from?
DOCTOR: Some kind of ship-wide communications system, I presume. — Yes, Hargreaves?
SHIP HARGREAVES: (ON PA SYSTEM) I’m afraid that there is a.. problem with Miss Nyssa.
TEGAN: What do you mean? What kind of a problem?
SHIP HARGREAVES: (ON PA SYSTEM) It seems that she has... disappeared.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 27
AQUITAINE: SCENE 12. SICK BAY
AQUITAINE: [NB: ANOTHER TIME ZONE. ]
NYSSA: (COMING TO) Ohhh... my head. What was that? (BEAT) Hargreaves, do you have anything for a headache?
NYSSA: Hargreaves? (SITS UP AND LOOKS AROUND) Hargreaves — where are you? (TO SELF) He’s gone...
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 28
AQUITAINE: SCENE 13. SICK BAY
AQUITAINE: FADE UP ON BEEP OF MEDICAL EQUIPMENT
DOCTOR: When you say Nyssa disappeared...
MEDIC HARGREAVES: My apologies, Sir. That description was imprecise and possibly misleading.
DOCTOR: So you didn’t actually see her vanish into thin air?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: No, Sir.
DOCTOR: But you didn’t see her leave Sickbay either?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: That is also true. I turned my back on Miss Nyssa to prepare an analgesic, and when I turned back she had gone.
TEGAN: So she could have just walked out of the room?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: The reason I do not consider that likely, Miss, is that she was not seen to do so by the cameras in the corridor beyond.
TEGAN: Oh. That’s weird.
DOCTOR: Do you have a camera in this room?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: No, Sir — for reasons of clinical ethics. For privacy reasons there are also no cameras in the bedrooms, the washrooms, the water closets, [the]
DOCTOR: (INTERRUPTING) Of course... (BEAT) Can you scan for life signs?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: Indeed, Sir. I regret to say that the only life signs on board are those of you and Miss Tegan, in this room.
TEGAN: Then where is she?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 29
DOCTOR: I’m quite sure there’s a rational explanation.
TEGAN: I’m not.
DOCTOR: Maybe Hargreaves’ sensors are on the blink? — This ship’s seen better days, after all. No offence, Hargreaves.
MEDIC HARGREAVES: I would take none even if I were able, Sir.
DOCTOR: Let’s retrace our steps. It’s a big ship - maybe she got lost on the way back to us...
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 30
AQUITAINE: SCENE 14. CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
NYSSA: WALKS BACK TOWARDS THE BOTANICAL GARDENS.
NYSSA: (SHOUTS) Doctor! Doctor, hello!
NYSSA: BUTLER HARGREAVES TRUNDLES UP BEHIND HER
BUTLER HARGREAVES: May I help you, Madam?
NYSSA: Ah! Where did you go?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I’m sorry, I do not understand the question. Go where?
NYSSA: You were with me one minute, and the next...
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I regret to say that I have never met you before, Madam.
NYSSA: Not you - the medical droid. I was just with hin...
BUTLER HARGREAVES: As I say, Madam - I have never met you before.
NYSSA: Now I really have a headache.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Would you like me to fetch the medical droid, Madam?
NYSSA: No. No, it’s fine. And it’s Nyssa. My name.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: A pleasure, Miss Nyssa. Would you like some tea?
NYSSA: No. No, I need to communicate with the botanical gardens. Can you do that?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Of course, Miss Nyssa. The Aquitaine is equipped with an intelligent Intracom system covering the entire ship.
NYSSA: Intracom?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 31
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Indeed. Wherever you are, simply speak your instructions out loud and you will be routed to either myself, or to whomever else you choose.
NYSSA: Hello? Doctor? Doctor, can you hear me?
NYSSA: A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
DOCTOR: (ON INTERCOM) Nyssa? Where are you?
NYSSA: Oh — thank goodness. I thought — well, I don’t know what I thought. I was all alone.
NYSSA: A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
DOCTOR: (ON INTERCOM) Where are you?
NYSSA: I’m walking towards the botanical gardens. Corridor... Gamma 12.
NYSSA: A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
DOCTOR: (ON INTERCOM) Stay where you are — we’1ll come to you.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 32
AQUITAINE: SCENE 15. CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
TEGAN: Nyssa? Nyssa! (BEAT) This is where she said she was, all right.
DOCTOR: Hargreaves, can you show us what that security camera is seeing?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: Of course, Sir. I will patch its output into my chest display.
ELECTRONIC: BEEP AS HE DOES SO
TEGAN: That’s.. snazzy.
DOCTOR: Just us... (BEAT) Nyssa? What are you looking at right now?
DOCTOR: A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
NYSSA: (OVER INTERCOM) I’m standing directly under a sign that says ‘Gamma 12’, facing toward the junction. Where are you?
DOCTOR: I’m. that’s exactly where we are.
TEGAN: This is weird. Are you sure there aren’t two corridor Gamma twelves?
DOCTOR: (SHARPLY) Both of which lead directly from the medical bay to the botanical gardens?
TEGAN: I’m worried too, you know?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: Doctor, I have identified something rather unusual.
DOCTOR: What’s that, Hargreaves?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: I have recalibrated my sensors and am now picking up a very faint life sign. But the signal is slightly adrift from its location. Like an echo.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 33
TEGAN: Doctor - when Nyssa speaks, she sounds like she’s a few seconds out! You know, like when there’s a satellite delay on TV...
DOCTOR: Yes, I was wondering about that...
DOCTOR: THE LIGHTS FLICKER AND THE SHIP SHAKES
TEGAN: Not again!
DOCTOR: Nyssa, did the lights just flicker where you are?
DOCTOR: A SHORT DELAY, AND THEN:
NYSSA: (OVER INTERCOM) Yes, Doctor. And the ship is shaking...
NYSSA: THE SHAKING BECOMES MORE VIOLENT
DOCTOR: It’s worse this time. More violent... Tegan, hold on to something.
TEGAN: (SHAKILY) I take back everything I ever said about your driving...
DOCTOR: Hargreaves, can you detect any external cause for the disturbance?
MEDIC HARGREAVES: Nothing, Sir; though my sensors — my sensors — my...
MEDIC HARGREAVES: A DEEP AND CAVERNOUS CRASH, LIKE A DISTANT THUNDERBOLT HITTING THE SHIP
MEDIC HARGREAVES: My... my.. (BEAT) I have engaged the emergency lighting, Sir.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Hargreaves. (BEAT) Is there something wrong?
DOCTOR: Hargreaves?
TEGAN: Now his lights have gone off...
TEGAN: THE SHAKING SUBSIDES
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 34
DOCTOR: I think that’s it.. (GETS HIS BREATH BACK) Nyssa, are you all right?
DOCTOR: Nyssa? Nyssa!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 35
AQUITAINE: SCENE 16. CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
AQUITAINE: THE SHAKING SUBSIDES
NYSSA: Doctor? Doctor, are you there...? Doctor!
NYSSA: JUST THE SOUND OF STATIC. HARGREAVES TRUNDLES UP BEHIND
NYSSA: Hargreaves? The intercom isn’t working. Listen.
MORE: STATIC
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Intra-ship communications are working fine, Miss.
NYSSA: Listen! There’s nobody there!
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Madam seems distressed. Would one like a cup of tea? I can offer Chai, Chamomile, Earl Grey, English breakfast...
NYSSA: No. Thank you.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Very well, Miss.
NYSSA: I don’t understand what’s happening. It felt as though the was being tossed from side to side.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I do not recall.
NYSSA: But you were here.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I was, Miss. But not with you.
NYSSA: What?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I regret to say that I have never met you before.
NYSSA: Hargreaves, you were here, with me. You were.
NYSSA: ship
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 36
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Alas, Miss — that cannot be true. My data records confirm that you were not here, and then you were.
NYSSA: But that’s impossible.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Nevertheless, it is a fact.
NYSSA: I was in a corridor, it was covered in vegetation; you were here. And there was writing on the wall, etched into the moss.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Forgive me, Miss — but I would not tolerate vegetable growth in the corridors of the Aquitaine. We have standards.
NYSSA: But there was.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I assure you, there isn’t.
NYSSA: The corridor was called Gamma 12.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: This is Gamma 12. Madam is standing in it.
NYSSA: But that’s impossible.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Quite so, Miss. Are you sure you wouldn’t like some tea?
NYSSA: (EXASPERATED SIGH) No. I don’t want tea. (ON INTERCOM) Hello? Doctor!
NYSSA: What was that?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Madam?
NYSSA: There’s something else in here with us. Listen.
HEAVY: BREATHING AND SLOW FOOTSTEPS, AS A FIGURE APPROACHES
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL)
NYSSA: What? Who are you?
NYSSA: What do you want?
NYSSA: Please...!
NYSSA: END OF EPISODE
NYSSA: Page 37
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 38

elements.text: PART TWO
NO REPRISE
SCENE 17. NARRATION/CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
FX: GENTLE HUM AND BEEPS OF SPACESHIP REBOOTING.

Today I am up with the lark. I water the plants, run the diagnostics, and do the dusting. After breakfast I rotate the ship eight inches to the left, so I can better chart the Caelum constellation. I vacuum the carpets. Luncheon is at one o’clock. At three o’clock I nip outside to clean the windows of the observation deck. Late afternoon I pass by the driving range, and briefly consider a round of golf with Butterworth, the service robot. But Butterworth is very stupid; it would be no contest. Instead I play chess, against myself. I win.

After supper I dim the lights in the empty ship sleeping quarters. At eleven o’clock my motion sensors detect two humanoid lifeforms in corridor Gamma 12. I shimmer over to them, and make my introductions.
Good evening. My name is Hargreaves. I am the ship’s computer. And valet.
I know. ‘Butler’ Hargreaves. Nice to see you again.
Welcome to the Aquitaine.
‘Welcome’? What do you [mean] -
Perhaps Sir and Madam would enjoy a cup of tea? I can offer Chai, Chamomile, Earl Grey, English breakfast...
Not right now, thank you Hargreaves.
Me neither. (SOTTO) What’s wrong with him?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page
A technical glitch, perhaps?
All my systems are functioning at optimum levels.
Do you know who we are?
No, Madam.
Well - I’m Tegan.
And I’m the Doctor. How do you do?
Delighted to make your acquaintance.
Unfortunately you already have. And that of a good friend of
mine, Nyssa. Do you remember her?
No, Sir. But I would be delighted to make her acquaintance
also.
And I’d be delighted to introduce you. Unfortunately, she seems
to have vanished...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 40
SCENE 18. CORRIDOR
HEAVY BREATHING AS A FIGURE WEARING A HEAVY
SUIT ADVANCES
(SCARED) Who are you? (BEAT) Won’t you at least let me see your face?
(RUSSIAN ACCENT) Wait! Please.
Did I scare you? My apologies.
Who are you?
This is Doctor Akunin.
That’s a radiation suit, isn’t it?

Originally. It offers good protection against all environmental hazards, but as you see, it is very heavy to wear. (CATCHES BREATH) I am exhausted. — It is so good to see you. You are with the rescue party, are you not?
Rescue...? No! No, I fear I’m in just as much need of rescuing as you.
(SUSPICIOUSLY) Then who are you? Why are you on the Aquitaine?
I’m Nyssa, of Traken. I’m a traveller. I landed on your ship, but I’ve been split up from my companions.
‘Companions’? How many companions?
Just the two. I was talking to them via the intracom; they said they were here, in this exact spot. But that’s impossible, of course.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 41
Of course...
Then the ship started shaking, and I couldn’t hear them anymore. (BEAT) Hargreaves says that I suddenly appeared here, out of nowhere.
Impossible also. (RELAXING) I think Hargreaves is not working one hundred per cent, no?
All my systems are working within normal levels, Doctor.
He says! Ha! We shall find your companions, Nyssa Ovtraken.
Just Nyssa.
Where did you last see them?
In the botanical gardens. But I was stung, so I left them to go to the sick bay.
Stung? By what?
Just a plant. It’s nothing.
Let me see, please.
ROLLS UP HER SLEEVE
Ogo...! [Or-goh: ‘wow’] I see, yes. It looks infected.
It’s quite sore.
I can help with this, I think. You must come with me — to my laboratory. We do not want the infection to spread, no?
No. No, I suppose not. And my companions?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 42
We will find them, do not worry, devochka moya. [deer-voch-kaa mai-yar: ‘My girl’] But first, we must see to you.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 43
SCENE 19. CORRIDOR GAMMA 12
ENTERS FROM A SIDE TURNING
(CALLING) Doctor! I’m back.
So I see. No luck, I assume?
(EXHAUSTED) No. Not a sign of her. (BEAT) Doctor, we’ve checked everywhere obvious. What’s left?
The other ninety-nine per cent of the ship.
Well, I suppose we’d better [get on with it] - (SHARPLY) is that a cup of tea you're drinking?
Er - yes. I got back some time ago, and...
And?
Yours has gone cold, I’m afraid.
Sir, if I might be so bold - there really is little to be gained in searching this entire ship. There are no human life Signs aboard, except for those of yourself and Miss Tegan.
Then what was all that traipsing about for?
You know me, Tegan. I prefer the belt and braces approach. By the way, Hargreaves - last time you checked you said you’d picked up a third life sign.
Did I, Sir?
Yes. Very faint.
Like an echo, you said.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 44
How odd. I have no recollection of such a conversation. But either way. the matter is moot. There is no such life sign now. Your friend is gone. As are my crew.
Your crew. Quite. Tell me, do you have records of where each crewmember was last seen?
I do. But if Sir is going to suggest checking these locations once more, I can assure you that my crew are still not there.
Oh, I’m well aware of that. But if we look more closely we may find some linking factor. A pattern.
PRINTOUT PRODUCED
What kind of pattern?
The kind that I won’t recognise until I’ve found it...
STOPS

I have retrieved the data you require, Sir. These are the locations where each member of the crew was last sighted. There are several square miles to cover. The first two, however, are close together.
(TAKING PRINTOUT) Captain Maynard, last seen on the observation deck. Lieutenant Savinio, last observed in the dining area...
Indeed. The other two are some distance away but are both located in the same quadrant of the ship.
(TAKING PRINTOUTS) Let me see. — Doctor Akunin in the sickbay. And Lieutenant Jennings in the botanical gardens...
Ah, really? In which case, we may already have met...
You mean — Caspar the Friendly Ghost? Brrr! She was spooky.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 45
She seemed to be in pain. I wonder why?
Shall I take those two, then - save us both tramping all over this ship again?
If you like, yes.
You’1l have to tell me what I’m looking for.
Dimensional flux. Gravitational anomalies, Konishi anomalies. Quantum phenomena. Three dimensional echoes. Four dimensional echoes, actually. Oh, and if we go down that route, time eddies.
Doctor, I couldn’t even say most of those, let alone recognise one.
Don’t worry, Hargreaves will know what to do.
Right. (BEAT) Then what will I be doing?
Um... taking a note of his answers? Have you got a pen?
No.
HE PRODUCES A PEN AND A YO-YO FROM HIS POCKET
Here. Oh, and take this as well, to check the gravity levels. You divide the time it takes to descend by the time taken to ascend, and that gives you a value you can approximate to earth normal.
It looks like a yo-yo.
It is a yo-yo. Now, good luck. Oh, and it shouldn’t need saying again, but — don’t touch any plants...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 46
SCENE 20. STAIRS.
AKUNIN AND NYSSA WALK DOWN SOME METAL STAIRS
Can we stop, please? Just for a minute.
It’s not much further. My laboratory is down just another level.
It’s so hot.
I think you have a fever. The infection taking hold.
You’ve seen this before?
One of my colleagues — Lieutenant Jennings. She too was bitten, and became quite ill. The symptoms — inflammation, rapid fever — the symptoms are the same.
And what happened to her? The Lieutenant?
I gave her the appropriate treatment. She was fine.
And where is she now?
She is here, on this ship. This is a big ship. Perhaps she is with your friends, yes? (BEAT) Nyssa? What’s wrong?
My legs. They feel numb.
It will pass. Here, take my arm. Not much further...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 47
SCENE 21. OBSERVATION DECK
(FRUSTRATED) Nothing...
Lm sorry, Sir?

There’s nothing out of the ordinary on the entire observation deck - just as there was nothing out of the ordinary in the dining hall. (BEAT) Well, other than the fact that your counterpart there seems to cook a three-course meal every evening, despite the continued failure of the crew to turn up to eat it.
(OVER INTERCOM) Doctor?
Yes, Tegan?
(OVER INTERCOM) I’m just coming up to the gardens. And that ghost is here again. I can see her name badge now, it is Lieutenant Jennings.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 48
SCENE 22. CORRIDOR BETA 15 [CONTINUOUS]
(OVER INTERCOM) Well, that’s something. Is anything different?
Not so far. She’s still not making any sense. Still running off round the corner every couple of minutes. It’s really creepy.
It wants me to die. It’s killing me, piece by piece. So it can live...
(OVER INTERCOM) Interesting.
Oh, and the gravity’s normal. I think. Tell the truth, I never was much good with a yo-yo.
(OVER INTERCOM) Well, look out for Hargreaves. The gardening droid should be there to meet you.
Will do. Tegan out.
I can feel it. Growing. Growing inside me. — You need to get away from me, Maurizio. Run. (MENACING) But run fast, Maurizio. (CHUCKLES) Run fast!
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 49
SCENE 23. INT. OBSERVATION DECK
(TO HARGREAVES) These ghosts. When we first met, you said they were just sounds. Voices. But we’ve actually seen one.
Indeed. I can only assume that my optical receptors do not have the requisite visual acuity to observe these — for want of a better term - ghosts.
They’re your crew, Hargreaves. In some form or another. Tell me - was Jennings unwell? Before her disappearance, I mean?
Not that I recall, Sir.
Then why is this echo of her in such pain? What happened to her?
If I might hazard a guess, Sir — it is possible she was injured during the ergostorm. A bout of turbulence, generally brief but potentially damaging —
— often experienced within the ergosphere of a black hole. I know what an ergostorm is, Hargreaves.
Sorry, Sir. According to my records the Aquitaine was hit by a particularly acute storm at around the same time Lieutenant Jennings was last seen.

Can you check all the system diagnostics that were running when the tremor hit? I want to know if you registered anything out of the ordinary - anything that isn’t explained by the physical effects of the storm.
Certainly. May I ask why?
Hargreaves — I think you may have cracked it.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 50
SCENE 24. LABORATORY
SLIDES OPEN. AKUNIN AND NYSSA ENTER
(FEELING WOOZY) I can’t feel my legs. Not at all.
The infection is spreading. Here - let me help you onto the (EFFORT) operating table.
Thank you, Doctor Akunin.
Sergei, please. That’s it. Now lie back.
This is your laboratory?
Correct.
But all these plants. I thought you were a doctor?
I am - a doctor of plants. A botanist. But I serve as the ship’s medic too — with some assistance from Hargreaves. The two disciplines are not so far apart, you know. Roll up your sleeve, please.
Is that an antidote?
It will help with the pain. (INJECTS NYSSA)
(GASPS) That stings.
The sedative will not take long. You should feel it starting to work now.
(WOOZILY) A little light-headed, yes...
It is a high dosage. Soon you will feel nothing.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 51
(DROWSY) And then... will you give me the antidote?
What antidote?
(DROWSY) To the... the infection.
You misunderstand me, Nyssa. There is no antidote.
(DROWSY) No... antidote?
All I can do is take the pain away. Hold still, please.
HEAVY METAL BONDS AROUND NYSSA’S ARMS AND LEGS
(DROWSY) What are you... what are you doing?
Restraining you. Please, don’t struggle. You need to sleep now. Sleep, Nyssa. Spee, zaSsypai. [Spee zas-ze-pie: ‘Rest, now.’ ]
WEAK) Please, no... (FALLS ASLEEP
Then, when you wake up, the pain will be gone.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 52
SCENE 25. OBSERVATION DECK
‘Cracked it’, Sir?
The pattern we’ve been looking for. The Aquitaine was also hit by some kind of disturbance just before Nyssa went missing.
I don’t re[call] —
I know you don’t remember, Hargreaves, but there was a physical tremor through the entire ship. Twice, in fact — the first barely perceptible, the second really rather unpleasant.
BEEPING
Initial analysis is complete, if you would care to examine my frontal display unit.
(STUDIES DISPLAY) Ah... that is interesting.
Are you referring to the power surge, Sir?
I am. But it’s not just a power surge.
No, Sir?
Look at that dimensional signature... It’s a temporal flicker! (BEAT) Of course! Hargreaves, this explains everything!
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 53
SCENE 26. CORRIDOR BETA FIFTEEN
Must... must be something I can do... Something he hasn’t thought of... (FADES OFF DOWN THE CORRIDOR)
Wait, where are you going..? (TO HERSELF) That’s not what you did before... (LOUDLY) Doctor?
(OVER INTERCOM) Yes, Tegan?
She’s off. Heading back towards the botanical gardens, I think.
(OVER INTERCOM) Jennings, you mean?
That’s new, isn’t it? (WALKING DETERMINEDLY) I’m going after her.
(OVER INTERCOM) Where are you? Hargreaves says he can’t see you on his scanners.
Corridor... Beta Fifteen. It’s not as overgrown as that one near the cultivation room. There’s some sort of moss growing on the walls. I think it’s covered up the cameras.
(OVER INTERCOM) Moss?
Oh, and on the floor. It’s weird. Looks like it’s moving.
(OVER INTERCOM) Moving?
Swaying to and fro, like grass in the wind. Except there isn’t any wind.
(OVER INTERCOM) It could be reacting to your presence, then. Be careful...
Uurghs Tt’ s..sticky.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 54
(OVER INTERCOM) For goodness’ sake, Tegan, don’t touch it!
I didn’t! I just stood on it. It’s sticky underfoot. Like someone’s spilt treacle on the floor.
(OVER INTERCOM) I think you should head back here.
No, I want to see where she’s going. Tegan out!
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 55
SCENE 27. LABORATORY
BEEPING OF MEDICAL EQUIPMENT. NYSSA WAKES, STRAPPED TO
Ohh, my head. (BEAT; REALISATION) I can’t move. (PULLS AT STRAPS, TO NO AVAIL) Doctor Akunin? Please, let me out of these straps. (BEAT) Doctor Akunin? Anyone?
NO ANSWER, JUST BEEPING OF MEDICAL EQUIPMENT
Hargreaves, are you there?
HARGREAVES COMES THROUGH INTRACOM
Always, madam.
Hargreaves, can you release these straps?
No, Miss.
Can you send one of your droids?
No, Miss. Doctor Akunin has authority in this area. If he required you to be restrained, I’m sure he had good reason.
Well, I’1ll just have to try to break the straps, then. They seem flexible, must be a weak alloy. — (BEGINS STRAINING AT
BONDS )
I’m not sure that is wise, Miss. You may damage the equipment.
BEGINS TO STRAIN, AND THEN BEND.
That’s the idea... Yes! Come on!
TWISTS AND BREAKS. WITH HER FREE ARM NYSSA: UNFASTENS THE
BONDS, AND SITS UP, PANTING WITH EXERTION.
There! — I don’t know my own strength. (STEPS DOWN OFF THE BENCH)
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 56
Please, Miss, you should wait for Doctor Akunin.
Why, where is he now?
Doctor Akunin is currently in access corridor Beta 5.
And how far away is that?
Ninety-three seconds at average walking speed.
You mean, he’s coming this way? — Hargreaves, I need your help.
I’m not sure I should, [madam] —
I’m discharging myself from Doctor Akunin’s care. Is that allowed?
(MISERABLY) It... is, madam.
Then you can help me, can’t you?
I.. suppose so, madam.

DOOR: SLIDES OPEN. AKUNIN AND NYSSA ENTER
NYSSA: (FEELING WOOZY) I can’t feel my legs. Not at all.
AKUNIN: The infection is spreading. Here - let me help you onto the (EFFORT) operating table.
NYSSA: Thank you, Doctor Akunin.
AKUNIN: Sergei, please. That’s it. Now lie back.
NYSSA: This is your laboratory?
AKUNIN: Correct.
NYSSA: But all these plants. I thought you were a doctor?
AKUNIN: I am - a doctor of plants. A botanist. But I serve as the ship’s medic too — with some assistance from Hargreaves. The two disciplines are not so far apart, you know. Roll up your sleeve, please.
NYSSA: Is that an antidote?
AKUNIN: It will help with the pain. (INJECTS NYSSA)
NYSSA: (GASPS) That stings.
AKUNIN: The sedative will not take long. You should feel it starting to work now.
NYSSA: (WOOZILY) A little light-headed, yes...
AKUNIN: It is a high dosage. Soon you will feel nothing.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 51
NYSSA: (DROWSY) And then... will you give me the antidote?
AKUNIN: What antidote?
NYSSA: (DROWSY) To the... the infection.
AKUNIN: You misunderstand me, Nyssa. There is no antidote.
NYSSA: (DROWSY) No... antidote?
AKUNIN: All I can do is take the pain away. Hold still, please.
FASTENS: HEAVY METAL BONDS AROUND NYSSA’S ARMS AND LEGS
NYSSA: (DROWSY) What are you... what are you doing?
AKUNIN: Restraining you. Please, don’t struggle. You need to sleep now. Sleep, Nyssa. Spee, zaSsypai. [Spee zas-ze-pie: ‘Rest, now.’ ]
AKUNIN: Then, when you wake up, the pain will be gone.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 52
AQUITAINE: SCENE 25. OBSERVATION DECK
BUTLER HARGREAVES: ‘Cracked it’, Sir?
DOCTOR: The pattern we’ve been looking for. The Aquitaine was also hit by some kind of disturbance just before Nyssa went missing.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I don’t re[call] —
DOCTOR: I know you don’t remember, Hargreaves, but there was a physical tremor through the entire ship. Twice, in fact — the first barely perceptible, the second really rather unpleasant.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Initial analysis is complete, if you would care to examine my frontal display unit.
DOCTOR: (STUDIES DISPLAY) Ah... that is interesting.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Are you referring to the power surge, Sir?
DOCTOR: I am. But it’s not just a power surge.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: No, Sir?
DOCTOR: Look at that dimensional signature... It’s a temporal flicker! (BEAT) Of course! Hargreaves, this explains everything!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 53
AQUITAINE: SCENE 26. CORRIDOR BETA FIFTEEN
FREYA: Must... must be something I can do... Something he hasn’t thought of... (FADES OFF DOWN THE CORRIDOR)
TEGAN: Wait, where are you going..? (TO HERSELF) That’s not what you did before... (LOUDLY) Doctor?
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Yes, Tegan?
TEGAN: She’s off. Heading back towards the botanical gardens, I think.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Jennings, you mean?
TEGAN: That’s new, isn’t it? (WALKING DETERMINEDLY) I’m going after her.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Where are you? Hargreaves says he can’t see you on his scanners.
TEGAN: Corridor... Beta Fifteen. It’s not as overgrown as that one near the cultivation room. There’s some sort of moss growing on the walls. I think it’s covered up the cameras.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Moss?
TEGAN: Oh, and on the floor. It’s weird. Looks like it’s moving.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Moving?
TEGAN: Swaying to and fro, like grass in the wind. Except there isn’t any wind.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) It could be reacting to your presence, then. Be careful...
TEGAN: Uurghs Tt’ s..sticky.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 54
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) For goodness’ sake, Tegan, don’t touch it!
TEGAN: I didn’t! I just stood on it. It’s sticky underfoot. Like someone’s spilt treacle on the floor.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) I think you should head back here.
TEGAN: No, I want to see where she’s going. Tegan out!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 55
AQUITAINE: SCENE 27. LABORATORY
STEADY: BEEPING OF MEDICAL EQUIPMENT. NYSSA WAKES, STRAPPED TO
NYSSA: Ohh, my head. (BEAT; REALISATION) I can’t move. (PULLS AT STRAPS, TO NO AVAIL) Doctor Akunin? Please, let me out of these straps. (BEAT) Doctor Akunin? Anyone?
NYSSA: NO ANSWER, JUST BEEPING OF MEDICAL EQUIPMENT
NYSSA: Hargreaves, are you there?
DISEMBODIED: HARGREAVES COMES THROUGH INTRACOM
SHIP HARGREAVES: Always, madam.
NYSSA: Hargreaves, can you release these straps?
SHIP HARGREAVES: No, Miss.
NYSSA: Can you send one of your droids?
SHIP HARGREAVES: No, Miss. Doctor Akunin has authority in this area. If he required you to be restrained, I’m sure he had good reason.
NYSSA: Well, I’1ll just have to try to break the straps, then. They seem flexible, must be a weak alloy. — (BEGINS STRAINING AT
METAL: BONDS )
SHIP HARGREAVES: I’m not sure that is wise, Miss. You may damage the equipment.
METAL: BEGINS TO STRAIN, AND THEN BEND.
NYSSA: That’s the idea... Yes! Come on!
METAL: TWISTS AND BREAKS. WITH HER FREE ARM NYSSA: UNFASTENS THE
OTHER: BONDS, AND SITS UP, PANTING WITH EXERTION.
NYSSA: There! — I don’t know my own strength. (STEPS DOWN OFF THE BENCH)
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 56
SHIP HARGREAVES: Please, Miss, you should wait for Doctor Akunin.
NYSSA: Why, where is he now?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Doctor Akunin is currently in access corridor Beta 5.
NYSSA: And how far away is that?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Ninety-three seconds at average walking speed.
NYSSA: You mean, he’s coming this way? — Hargreaves, I need your help.
SHIP HARGREAVES: I’m not sure I should, [madam] —
NYSSA: I’m discharging myself from Doctor Akunin’s care. Is that allowed?
SHIP HARGREAVES: (MISERABLY) It... is, madam.
NYSSA: Then you can help me, can’t you?
SHIP HARGREAVES: I.. suppose so, madam.
NYSSA: Good!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 57
AQUITAINE: SCENE 28. OBSERVATION DECK
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Doctor, I have the diagnostics you requested for the other three crew members.
DOCTOR: Excellent. (EXAMINES HARGREAVES’ DISPLAY) Now, let’s see... There, that’s a definite temporal flicker when Lieutenant Savinio was enjoying his last meal in the dining room... And again when Doctor Akunin disappeared from the sickbay... And once again, right here on the observation deck when Captain Maynard vanished. (BEAT) You see, Hargreaves? It’s not where they are, but when. Your crew has been lost in time.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I am at a loss to explain how I did not draw the same conclusion.
DOCTOR: Hargreaves... have you ever wondered why you’re never able to keep on top of your to-do list?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Constantly, Sir. In fact, it becomes more of a mystery as the days go on.
DOCTOR: You do realise that you’ve been rebooting every time one of these ergostorms hits the ship?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Rebooting, Sir?
DOCTOR: Yes. The power surge trips your circuits and to avoid damage, the ship - not to put too fine a point on it - switches you off and switches you on again.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: That sounds most irregular, Sir. And surely I would rem[ember ]... Oh. I see.
DOCTOR: (SOFTLY) It’s all here, I’m afraid. Every time the storm hits, you return to your last system restore point and start all over again. It’s why you don’t remember us. And why nothing ever seems to get done.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: But my last system restore point was only seven days ago.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 58
DOCTOR: No, I think it was longer ago than that. — Look around you. The rapid growth of those plants in the cultivation lab? Perhaps it wasn’t so rapid after all. And all the dust... Rather more than seven days’ worth, no matter how far behind you’ve got with the chores. If you’d just give me access to your control panel... Thank you.
TAPS: AWAY AT HARGREAVES’ CONTROL PANEL
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Doctor, I feel rather anxious.
DOCTOR: It’ll pass. You just need to — (STOPS) Ah. That is a long time.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Sir?
DOCTOR: I’ve adjusted your system clock to show how much time has actually passed. Simple, really - there’s a record of each shutdown and a record of each reboot, so you just need to total them all up.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Doctor? How long has it been?
DOCTOR: It seems the Aquitaine has been circling this black hole for slightly over fifty years...
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 59
AQUITAINE: SCENE 29. DELETED
AQUITAINE: SCENE 30. BOTANICAL GARDENS
TROPICAL: RAINFOREST SOUNDS. FOOTSTEPS THROUGH UNDERGROWTH.
FREYA: (OFF) It’s burning... burning inside!
TEGAN: (STOPPING, TO SELF) Who are you talking to? Is there someone else there? (ALOUD) Jennings? If you can hear me...
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Did you say something, Tegan?
TEGAN: Crikey, Doc! You made me jump. I was just talking to the ghost. We’re back in the botanical gardens — near the TARDIS, I can see it from here.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) You’re still following her?
TEGAN: She’s getting ahead of me now. I can’t keep up - this mossy stuff keeps sticking to my shoes.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) Tegan, you might as well come back. I think I know what’s happened to [Nyssa].
TEGAN: (STICKING IN MUD, NEARLY FALLING OVER) Rabbits!
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) What now?
TEGAN: I nearly fell over. My shoe’s stuck fast.
TEGAN: PULLS AT HER FOOT. THE MOSS REACTS BY STICKING FASTER TO
HER: SHOE
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) I did tell you to be careful!
STICKY: SOUNDS AS THE MOSS STARTS TO GROW PERCEPTIBLY
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 60
TEGAN: (WORRIED) Doctor? Doctor! This is weird!
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) What’s weird?
TEGAN: I think this moss is growing... (MORE SOUNDS OF MOSS TENDRILS EXTENDING) It is! When I try and pull my foot away, it grows little bit more!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 61
AQUITAINE: SCENE 31. OBSERVATION DECK [CONTINUOUS]
DOCTOR: Tegan, don’t move!
TEGAN: (OVER INTERCOM) How will I get free if I don’t move?
DOCTOR: The moss wants you to move! The more you struggle, the more it will tighten its grip - like quicksand.
TEGAN: (OVER INTERCOM) Right. Okay, yeah, I understand. Don’t move.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Hargreaves, this is urgent. The way that moss is behaving, it’s clearly hostile to animal life.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Hostile, Sir?
DOCTOR: Worst case, carnivorous. If Tegan loses her balance...
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I understand.
DOCTOR: Can you send a droid to help free her?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I’m afraid that will not be possible. The growth in question has proven inimical to my counterpart’s drive systems.
DOCTOR: Then I’ll have to go myself. Is there a clear route to the gardens?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Via corridor Beta Seventeen — yes, Sir.
DOCTOR: Excellent. (LOUDLY) Tegan? Don’t panic. I’m coming...
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 62
AQUITAINE: SCENE 32. PLANT NURSERY
DOOR: SWOOSHES OPEN; NYSSA RUNS IN.
NYSSA: (SOTTO) Hargreaves? Where am I now?
SHIP HARGREAVES: (SOTTO) Plant Nursery Seven-A, Miss. (BEAT) Perhaps you would care to know that Dr Akunin has pursued you from his laboratory, and is heading your way?
NYSSA: What? (SOTTO) Hargreaves, there’s nowhere to hide!
SHIP HARGREAVES: (SOTTO) The low-level lighting is designed for the growth of non-photosynthetic algae, Miss. I calculate that you would stand least chance of detection behind the culture tank to your right.
SHIP HARGREAVES: WE FOLLOW HER AS SHE HIDES IN A CORNER, BREATHING HARD. THE
DOOR: OPENS AGAIN AND AKUNIN ENTERS, CAUTIOUSLY. HE ADDRESSES THE APPARENTLY EMPTY ROOM.
AKUNIN: Hargreaves will not tell me where you are, Nyssa. Patient confidentiality, he says. Patient confidentiality! (CHUCKLES) Very good.
WALKS: CLOSER
AKUNIN: But it doesn’t matter, of course. You really think you can hide from me? I know every inch of this vessel. From the observation deck to the engine room, every last inch. I’ve had a long time
AKUNIN: to learn it.
AKUNIN: But let’s suppose I do not find you, Nyssa, what then? You see, the minute you touched that plant, your fate was sealed. You cannot run from what is going to happen to you. You cannot hide from it. I am the only person who can help.
AKUNIN: HE WANDERS AWAY, STILL TALKING
AKUNIN: I have seen the infection take hold. You will endure the most terrible suffering, Nyssa. The pain will be unbearable, beyond imagining. I know, Nyssa — I’ve seen it.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 63
AQUITAINE: HE RETURNS, AND WALKS EVER CLOSER TO NYSSA’S HIDING PLACE. WE
HEAR: HER SHALLOW BREATHING.
AKUNIN: Spare yourself. I can help you. You’ll go to sleep, you’1ll know nothing of it. Come out. Show yourself. Come to me, Nyssa. Ot sood’bee ne ooi-dyosh [art sood-bee nee wee-deeyosh] — ‘You cannot escape your fate.’
AKUNIN: WITH A CLATTER OF OVERTURNED MACHINERY, NYSSA DARTS FROM HER
HIDING: PLACE.
NYSSA: (DESPERATELY) Hargreaves, the door!
AKUNIN: Ah, there you are! — Come back!
DOOR: SWOOSHES SHUT.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 64
AQUITAINE: SCENE 33. BOTANICAL GARDENS
TROPICAL: RAINFOREST.
TEGAN: Doctor? Doctor, the moss is growing... fast. It’s over my ankle now. I’m trying to keep still, but it’s not easy. (SOUND OF
MOSS: SUCKING AT HER LEG) Doctor, I can feel it sucking at me... like some kind of leech!
MOSS: A RUSTLING IN THE BUSHES, SOME WAY OFF
TEGAN: Who’s that? Is there someone there?
MORE: RUSTLING, AS IF A FIGURE IS SLOWLY AND UNSURELY MOVING
TEGAN: Nyssa? Is that you?
MORE: RUSTLING — PERCEPTIBLY CLOSER
TEGAN: Doctor? Hargreaves?
PLANT CREATURE: (UNPLEASANT RASPING EXHALATION, ACCOMPANIED BY THE STRANGE
CHATTERING: SOUND OF ITS MANY FACIAL TENDRILS )
TEGAN: Look, who is that? Why won’t you answer me?
PLANT CREATURE: THE CREATURE TAKES ANOTHER STEP THROUGH THE UNDERGROWTH
TEGAN: (SHOUTS) Doctor! Doctor, can you hear me?
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) (BREATHLESS) Yes, Tegan?
TEGAN: (NORMALLY) There’s someone here...
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) What do you mean, someone?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 65
TEGAN: In the botanical gardens. There’s someone here. Or something.
DOCTOR: Something?
TEGAN: It doesn’t... it doesn’t sound human.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 66
AQUITAINE: SCENE 34. OBSERVATION DECK
NYSSA: RUNS DOWN A CORRIDOR AND REACHES A DOOR ADJACENT TO A
LARGE: WINDOW.
NYSSA: (BREATHLESS) Where am I now?
SHIP HARGREAVES: The forward observation deck, Miss. Offering one of the finest aspects in the entire ship.
NYSSA: Never mind the view, Hargreaves - does this door open?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Unfortunately, Miss, that is the entrance to the upper airlock.
NYSSA: What...?
SHIP HARGREAVES: You are at the furthest extremity of the ship. There is nowhere to go but back. I’m sorry.
AKUNIN: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) Ah, there you are. Admiring the view? Beautiful, isn’t it?
NYSSA: Please. Keep away.
AKUNIN: The Caelum constellation. I was twenty-seven when I first saw it. A long time ago now.
NYSSA: I’m a scientist. I can find an antidote.
DISTANT: RUMBLE AND CREAK OF METAL
AKUNIN: You have my sympathies, Nyssa, you really do. But as a scientist, you can see that there is only one logical course of action. Come with me.
NYSSA: No...
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 67
AKUNIN: There’s nowhere to run, Nyssa.
SHIP: BEGINS TO VIOLENTLY SHAKE.
AKUNIN: (REALISATION DAWNING) No! Not now! Ne seichas! Niet! [nee see- chas! nee-et: Not now! No!]
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 68
AQUITAINE: SCENE 35. CORRIDOR BETA SEVENTEEN/BOTANICAL GARDENS
DOCTOR: RUNNING THROUGH UNDERGROWTH
TEGAN: (OVER INTERCOM) Doctor, please hurry.
DOCTOR: I’ll be with you any moment now - had to take the scenic route,
DOCTOR: or else we'd both be stuck. Are you still near the TARDIS?
TEGAN: (OVER INTERCOM) Of course I am! Where do you think I’ve gone?
DOCTOR: Sorry. This.. creature. Can it see you?
DOCTOR: CROSS TO GARDENS.
TEGAN: (QUIETLY) I don’t know. I don’t think so.
DOCTOR: (OVER INTERCOM) What was that? Tegan, I can’t hear you.
TEGAN: (QUIETLY) It only moves when I speak. Doctor, I think it’s
TEGAN: hunting me...
CROSS: BACK TO CORRIDOR.
DOCTOR: Just try to stay calm. And keep your balance!
SHIP: BEGINS TO VIOLENTLY SHAKE.
DOCTOR: Oh no...
TEGAN: (OVER INTERCOM) Doctor? The ship’s
DOCTOR: Yes, here too. Hargreaves?
SHIP HARGREAVES: (OVER INTERCOM) Yes, Doctor?
DOCTOR: What do your scanners say? Is this
DOCTOR: shaking again!
DOCTOR: another ergostorm?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 69
SHIP HARGREAVES: (OVER INTERCOM) I believe so, Doctor. My diagnostic functions [are —]
SHIP HARGREAVES: AS BEFORE, DEEP AND CAVERNOUS CRASH — LIKE A DISTANT
THUNDERBOLT: — AS THE TIME STORM HITS THE SHIP
SHIP HARGREAVES: (OVER INTERCOM) Are... are.. are...
DOCTOR: Hargreaves? Oh, not again!
DOCTOR: STUMBLES ON THROUGH DOORWAY, INTO:
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 70
AQUITAINE: SCENE 36. BOTANICAL GARDENS [CONTINUOUS]
DOCTOR: (BREATHLESS) Tegan, I’m here. Where are you? Are you safe?
SHAKING: SUBSIDES.
DOCTOR: I think we’re through the worst of it. (BEAT) Tegan, are you there? (BEAT) Tegan?!
DOCTOR: The TARDIS. Where did I leave the TARDIS?
DOCTOR: HE STUMBLES ON THROUGH THE UNDERGROWTH
DOCTOR: Ah yes! Underneath that rather attractive Oeno- (STOPS DEAD) carpus. (REALISATION) Oh no. (ALOUD) Hargreaves? Is it my imagination, or is there a rather large hole where the patch of forest containing my TARDIS used to be? (BEAT) Hargreaves?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 71
AQUITAINE: SCENE 37. OBSERVATION DECK
SHAKING: SUBSIDES. AKUNIN HAS VANISHED.
NYSSA: Doctor Akunin? (TO SELF) Where did he go? (CALLING) Hargreaves? Hargreaves!
NYSSA: SILENCE. WE HEAR THE SHIP SYSTEMS REBOOTING AND WARMING UP.
SHIP HARGREAVES: Good evening, madam.
NYSSA: Nyssa. It’s Nyssa.
SHIP HARGREAVES: My apologies. Would ‘Miss Nyssa’ care for a cup of tea?
NYSSA: (DISTRACTED) Tea?
SHIP HARGREAVES: I have Chai, Chamomile, Earl Grey, English...
NYSSA: Where did he go?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Where did who go, madam?
NYSSA: Doctor Akunin. He was here a minute ago.
SHIP HARGREAVES: He was not, madam. And neither, for that matter, were you.
NYSSA: (IRRITATED, UNDER BREATH) Or maybe you just have a very short memory. (NORMAL) Tell me Hargreaves, have we met before?
SHIP HARGREAVES: No, madam.
NYSSA: Have you met my companions? The Doctor — not Akunin, a different Doctor. My Doctor. And Tegan.
SHIP HARGREAVES: No, madam.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 72
NYSSA: Are there any other life signs on board this vessel?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Yes, madam.
NYSSA: Yes? Who?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Captain Maynard, the commander of the Aquitaine.
NYSSA: Can I speak to the Captain?
SHIP HARGREAVES: That may be difficult, Miss. Captain Maynard is sleeping, and must not be disturbed.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 73
AQUITAINE: SCENE 38. CORRIDOR
AQUITAINE: WE HEAR THE SHIP SYSTEMS REBOOTING AND WARMING UP. BUTLER HARGREAVES AND DOCTOR MEET IN A CORRIDOR, STOPPING SIMULTANEOUSLY.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Good evening, sir.
DOCTOR: Ah, Hargreaves. And then there were two.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: And how is sir today?
DOCTOR: I’ve had better. I seem to have mislaid both of my companions. Not to mention my ship. It’s really rather worrying.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I’m sorry to hear that, sir. Perhaps one would like some tea? I have Chai, Chamomile...
DOCTOR: English breakfast. Thank you, Hargreaves.
HARGREAVES: BEGINS BREWING SOME TEA IN HIS CHEST CAVITY
DOCTOR: I find tea helps me think, you see. (BEAT) You don’t remember me, do you Hargreaves?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Remember you, sir?
DOCTOR: Remember meeting me. Before.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I’ve never met you before, sir. Your tea.
DOCTOR: (TAKES TEA) Thank you. — You’ve rebooted, Hargreaves. Every time there’s a disturbance you reboot, hence you not remembering anything. I’ve already told you this, by the way.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: I’m afraid I don’t recall.
DOCTOR: (SIPS TEA) Excellent tea. — But there’s a bigger problem, alas.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 74
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Oh dear me.
DOCTOR: I think the disturbances — ergostorms, you call them - are becoming more frequent. This time it was fifty minutes between storms; the time before I measured it as fifty-six. Do you know what that means?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Does it mean something bad, sir?
DOCTOR: Black holes warp time and space, you see? Now, sitting up here safely in the ergosphere, we shouldn’t be affected by any of that. Unfortunately, I think that black hole out there is collapsing.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Goodness.
DOCTOR: Collapsing, and pulling this ship slowly towards it, sucking it closer inch by inch. Every time we’re pulled closer to the event horizon, the time distortion effect becomes worse, hence the more-frequent time storms.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Oh dear, Sir. That does sound alarming.
DOCTOR: According to my calculations, the next time storm will be in 43 minutes. And at that rate of increase the Aquitaine, and everyone aboard, will be destroyed in a little over... two hours.
DOCTOR: END OF EPISODE
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 75

elements.text: PART THREE
NO REPRISE
SCENE 39. BOTANICAL GARDENS
(QUIETLY) Hargreaves? Hargreaves, are you there?
(OVER INTERCOM) Yes, Miss?
(QUIETLY) Thank goodness! Hargreaves, there was something here just now. Some sort of creature — I thought it was stalking me. Is it — is it still here?
There are no lifeforms present other than yourself, Miss.
Weird. Oh well, one thing at a time - I still need to get free of this man-eating moss before I lose more than just my shoes. (SIGHS) Where’s the Doctor? He said he was nearly here.
I’m not sure to whom you are referring, Miss. Are you requiring Doctor Akunin? If so, I am afraid I am unable to help.
Doctor who? No, I want the Doctor. He’s probably got lost. Can you tell him I’m near the [TARDIS] - (BEAT) Hang on, what’s
happened to the TARDIS?
‘TARDIS’, Miss?
It was there a minute ago, and now it isn’t. Great. I‘11l probably get the blame for that as well...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 76
SCENE 40. CRYOGENIC CHAMBERS
SWISH OF DOOR OPENING. CHILLY HUM OF CRYOSLEEP CHAMBERS.
(WALKING IN) Captain Maynard’s in here?
That’s correct, madam. The sleeping quarters. As I said, Madam, the Captain must not be disturbed!
It’s cold.. (BEAT) Hold on - these are cryogenic chambers!

Yes, Miss. The crew were originally placed in suspended animation for the duration of the voyage to the Caelum constellation. But Captain Maynard was put back into cryosleep more recently, after she fell ill.
Under whose advice?
Doctor Akunin. When the Captain became incapacitated, he became ranking officer.
But Akunin isn’t here, is he? He vanished, earlier. (AN IDEA) Which makes me ranking officer.
Madam?
Your function is to serve the humans aboard the Aquitaine, correct? So if I am the only humanoid being on board, then I must be the ranking officer.
(WHIRRS, COGITATES, THEN:) Yes, madam.
Good. Then I order you to wake Captain Maynard.
Certainly, madam. (TRUNDLES OVER TO SLEEPING POD) Captain Maynard is in sleeping bay two. (STOPS) Initiating waking sequence... now.
ELECTRONIC BEEPS. SLOW DECOMPRESSION.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 77
SCENE 41. CREW ROOM
OPENS. BUTLER HARGREAVES ENTERS. BEAT.
(COUGHS POLITELY) A-hem.
(PREOCCUPIED) Ah. Hargreaves. Do you have the data from the recent storm?
