DOCTOR: Did you hear what I said? The clock is ticking, Akunin. And it’s nearly midnight.
AKUNIN: I don’t believe you. There has to be another way. (BEAT) Hargreaves — restrain the Doctor!
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Certainly, Sir.
DOCTOR: What?
AKUNIN: You’re a danger to this ship, Doctor. You need to be stopped!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 100
AQUITAINE: SCENE 53. CORRIDOR BETA NINETEEN
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) Hargreaves?
SHIP HARGREAVES: Yes, Lieutenant?
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) Sshhh!
SHIP HARGREAVES: (SOTTO) My apologies.
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) Hargreaves, there’s an unidentified lifeform in corridor beta nineteen. Can you see it?
SHIP HARGREAVES: (SOTTO) I can indeed, Lieutenant. It is a most peculiar specimen. Possibly some kind of mobile plant-life.
TEGAN: (SOTTO) Plant life?!
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) I want you to close bulkheads B and C along that corridor. You got that? Seal the thing off, and give us time to get to safety.
SHIP HARGREAVES: (SOTTO) I can do that, Sir. May I enquire - is Sir proposing to return to the engineering level?
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) Yes, of course — (REALISATION) Damn!
TEGAN: (SOTTO) What’s wrong?
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) The creature is between us and the elevator. We seal it in, we cut ourselves off from the other decks.
TEGAN: (SOTTO) That’s okay, though? Staying here’s less dangerous than having that thing on the loose, surely?
SAVINIO: (SOTTO) I have to get back to maintenance. And you have to come with me. Please don’t argue.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 101
TEGAN: Hey! Get your hands off me!
SAVINIO: Sshhh! (HISSED) Tegan, you’re not being rational!
PLANT: CREATURE LUMBERING FORWARD FROM OFF
TEGAN: Oh, and you are? Look, I understand you’re still sore about losing Jennings, but — (REALISATION) Is that it? You’re taking
TEGAN: me back to your hidey-hole as her replacement?!
SHIP HARGREAVES: Sir, Madam, if I might interrupt...?
SAVINIO: Shut up, Hargreaves!
SHIP HARGREAVES: It’s just that the life form [is —]
PLANT: CREATURE’S VILE RATTLING BREATH AS IT LOOMS OVER SAVINIO
TEGAN: (ALARM) Behind you!
TEGAN: IT SHOOTS OUT A TENDRIL AND STABS HIM IN THE SHOULDER
SAVINIO: Aaaaarghhh!
TEGAN: (TO PLANT CREATURE) Get away from him!
SAVINIO: It... stabbed me...!
TEGAN: Only in the shoulder. Same nasty trick as that plant did to Nyssa.
PLANT: CREATURE RATTLING MENACINGLY
TEGAN: Keep back! I’m warning you...!
SHIP HARGREAVES: Madam, if I might make a suggestion...?
TEGAN: I’m all ears, Hargreaves!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 102
SHIP HARGREAVES: (SOTTO) On the wall to your right, you will find a carbon dioxide extinguisher, containing pressurised foam for manual use in emergencies.
TEGAN: Such as attacks by alien plant monsters?!
SAVINIO: (PAINED) It’s cold. It might... give us time...
TEGAN: To get to the elevator, I get it.
COLLECTS: EXTINGUISHER FROM WALL
TEGAN: Alright — Savinio, get ready to run. If you can run.
SAVINIO: I'll have to.
CREATURE: MOVES CLOSER.
TEGAN: Ready. Three, two, one, and —
SHE: SETS OFF EXTINGUISHER.
TEGAN: Now, Savinio. Run!!!
SHE: DROPS EXTINGUISHER. THEY STUMBLE-HOBBLE AWAY WHILE THE
CREATURE: SHRIEKS
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 103
AQUITAINE: SCENE 54. BOTANICAL GARDENS
DOCTOR: We have a very small window of opportunity, Akunin. It’s our only hope.
AKUNIN: The Aquitaine cannot be destroyed. It is far more important than you realise.
DOCTOR: I can save your friends, and I can save mine. Just give me the chance.
AKUNIN: I’m not a selfish man, Doctor. You wish to rescue your companions, I understand. But can you set their lives against the destruction of an entire species?
DOCTOR: What species? What are you talking about?
AKUNIN: It began when Lieutenant Jennings became infected by one of the plant samples we had taken from a dying planet, Vetrius Three. A very promising sample, with many potential applications for human health — but it needed to be handled wth care. Freya was... clumsy. The infection spread rapidly, and I realised the only way to halt its spread was to place her into suspended animation while I searched for a cure.
DOCTOR: But you couldn’t find one?
AKUNIN: Oh no, I found one. That was simple — it can be found in the extract of the plant itself. But the plant is quite unique, you see. It produces no seeds; its only method of reproduction is to infect another organism with its DNA. The end result is something entirely new. A new species. So you see my dilemma? As a fellow scientist?
DOCTOR: No, I’m not sure that I do.
AKUNIN: To ‘cure’ the infection would be to kill it. I would be murdering a new species, butchering it at birth.
DOCTOR: I see. And you think that would be... what? Unethical?
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 104
AKUNIN: Exactly! The two lifeforms were incompatible — both would have died. I have been working instead to help marry the two species, to unite them. While my patients sleep, the new species grows and flowers inside them.
DOCTOR: (SICKENED) You’ve been using your fellow crewmembers as host bodies?
AKUNIN: I’ve created a new species, Doctor. Can you imagine anything finer? For men of science, such as ourselves? Anything nobler? You do understand, don’t you Doctor?
DOCTOR: I certainly do.
AKUNIN: I have done the impossible. I have created life. They are my creation, my progeny! I call them my Akunites!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 105
AQUITAINE: SCENE 55. INT ELEVATOR
DOOR: CLOSES. SAVINIO SLUMPS TO THE FLOOR.
SAVINIO: (PAINED BREATHING) Engineering deck. Deck Fourteen.
TEGAN: But the Doctor!
SAVINIO: (EXASPERATED) The Doctor...! He’s not coming, Tegan!
TEGAN: He is! I’m going to the observation deck.
TEGAN: Deck... three. (PRESSES BUTTON) That’s where he’ll be. (BEAT) aren’t we going anywhere? Hargreaves, why aren’t we moving?
SHIP HARGREAVES: My apologies, Madam. Only authorised personnel are permitted
SHIP HARGREAVES: Why
SHIP HARGREAVES: to
SHIP HARGREAVES: use the elevators, a stricture enforced via the use of retinal
SHIP HARGREAVES: scans.
TEGAN: (SIGHS) Come on, then. Guess we’ll have to do it your way after all, Savinio. — Savinio? Snap out of it, Savinio!
SAVINIO: (SLURRING) There’s something... wrong. I’ve been... poisoned.
TEGAN: No... No!
SHE: BANGS THE DOOR IN FRUSTRATION
SHIP HARGREAVES: Madam, I thought you ought to know that the creature outside appears to have recovered.
SHIP HARGREAVES: A BANG ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE LIFT DOORS.
TEGAN: Hargreaves, whatever else happens, keep these doors shut.
SHIP HARGREAVES: Certainly, madam.
TEGAN: Savinio, let me help you up. Just look into the screen, then can be on our way.
TEGAN: we
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 106
TEGAN: /SAVINIO:
TEGAN: Here, is it? — Go on, Hargreaves. Do your stuff.
SHIP HARGREAVES: Retinal scan... not recognised, I’m afraid.
TEGAN: What do you mean? It’s Savinio! Look at him!
SHIP HARGREAVES: I’m afraid the gentleman’s retinal scan does not match my records.
TEGAN: His eyes do look kinda funny. Sort of... yellow.
SAVINIO: (CROAKS) Hargreaves... it’s me, Savinio. I’m ill. Please.
SHIP HARGREAVES: itm ‘SsOLury;> Sirs 1 cannot.
TEGAN: Oh, come on!
SHE: BANGS THE SIDE OF THE LIFT IN FRUSTRATION. BEAT. MORE BANGING FROM OUTSIDE.
TEGAN: And you can be quiet!
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 107
AQUITAINE: SCENE 56. CORRIDOR
NYSSA: SUPPORTS MAYNARD AS THEY STUMBLE ALONG
NYSSA: This way, Captain. Back to the Sleeping Bay.
MAYNARD: I can’t... breathe. There’s something in my lungs. The infection.
NYSSA: It’s not far. Come on.
MAYNARD: I can feel it, Nyssa.. it’s in my head. Something alien, grasping at my mind.
NYSSA: Then fight it. We can’t be more than a few minutes away.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Sixteen minutes, at your current speed.
MAYNARD: You have to go. Leave me.
NYSSA: No, that’s not going to happen.
MAYNARD: Yes! There’s something growing right here Nyssa, behind my eyes. Something that wants you. That wants to feed on you. It can smell your human scent, Nyssa. And it’s making my heart beat faster.
NYSSA: It’s not far...!
MAYNARD: You need to run. You get to get yourself as far away from me as possible.
NYSSA: But...
MAYNARD: Now! Run!
NYSSA: RUNS
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 108
AQUITAINE: SCENE 57. BOTANICAL GARDENS
DOCTOR: Well, Doctor Akunin - I’m lost for words. Truly.
AKUNIN: Thank you.
DOCTOR: To engineer a new lifeform.. quite brilliant. And you say you used your fellow crewmembers for the task?
AKUNIN: Jennings was more of a test subject, an experiment. Maynard though, she is — or was - the host to my first-born. I thought it only fitting that the Captain should be the first true Akunite.
DOCTOR: And Nyssa?
AKUNIN: She too has been infected by one of my hybrids. She too will have evolved into an Akunite.
DOCTOR: Are you listening to this, Hargreaves?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: With great interest, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Good. For a man of such high morals, Akunin, you have a very poor grasp of robotic ethics.
AKUNIN: Robotic ethics?! What are you talking about?
DOCTOR: A robot — or ship’s computer - may not injure a human being ov...
DOCTOR: well, you tell us, Hargreaves.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Or through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.
DOCTOR: First law of robotics. Feeling active, Hargreaves?
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Absolutely, Sir.
SHIP: ENGINES POWERING UP
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 109
AKUNIN: What are you doing?
DOCTOR: You talk of ethics? Jennings and Maynard trusted you to save their lives, and what did you do? (BEAT) Hargreaves, take this ship into the black hole.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Plotting a course now, Sir.
AKUNIN: But I am ranking officer!
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Not anymore, Dr Akunin. You are relieved of command.
AKUNIN: Stop! Let go of me!
BUTLER HARGREAVES: In the circumstances I have no option other than to restrain you, sir.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: THE ENGINES ROAR. AN OMINOUS METALLIC GROAN
BUTLER HARGREAVES: Two minutes until the event horizon, Doctor.
AKUNIN: You’1ll kill us all!
AKUNIN: THE SHIP SHAKES.
BUTLER HARGREAVES: One hundred seconds.
AKUNIN: Turn this ship around!
GHOSTLY: VOICES BEGIN TO SWIRL AROUND THE ROOM, EG:
TEGAN: [FROM SCENE 30] Doctor? Doctor! This is weird!
NYSSA: [FROM SCENE 16] There’s something else in here with us. Listen.
FREYA: [FROM SCENE 11] Ohhhh... Oh, it hurts. It hurts so much. (SOBS) Make it stop... Sergei, please.
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 110
MAYNARD: [FROM SCENE 56] [..] 1t’s in my head. Something alien, grasping at my mind.
DOCTOR: It’s too late now, Akunin. The time fracture is opening up!
MORE: VIOLENT SHAKING AND ROAR OF SHIP ENGINES.
MORE: END OF EPISODE
AQUITAINE: by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 111

elements.text: PART FOUR
It’s too late now, Akunin. The time fracture is opening up!
VIOLENT SHAKING AND ROAR OF SHIP ENGINES.
SCENE 58. BOTANICAL GARDENS [CONTINUOUS]
SIRENS SOUND AS THE AQUITAINE PLUNGES INTO THE BLACK HOLE. METAL RENT & TWISTED; VIOLENT SHAKING.
VOICES [AS ABOVE] CONTINUE TO SWIRL AND ECHO, UNDER:
What’s happening?
The past... the future... is breaking through. (DECISIVELY) Fancy an adventure, Hargreaves?
Where are we going, Sir?
Into the maelstrom.
That’s madness!
Stay here or follow us, I really don’t care.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 112
SCENE 59. INT ELEVATOR
It’s been quiet for a while now. (BEAT) Maybe it’s got bored and gone away.
(SLOW AND HOARSE — DYING) Do you think that creature used to be human? That it might have been Jennings? Or your friend?
I’m trying not to think about that.
Then that’s what’s happening to me.
Don’t be so sure. I saw the plant that infected Nyssa, and that thing out there wasn’t one of those. I think it just wanted to kill you.
SHIP SHAKES, RATTLING THE ELEVATOR IN ITS CAGE
Another time storm?
Feels like it. That’s all we need.
This Doctor of yours... he’s not coming.

Oh, he’ll come. Just when we’re least expecting it, too. (BEAT) You'd like him, you know. Well - probably. He is the most annoying man I’ve ever met, admittedly. And he does keep getting me into situations like this... (BEAT) But I keep coming back. I can’t even blame him for this one. We’re only here because he was trying to help.
And your other friend?
Nyssa. She’s lovely. Just... too good for this world. (BEAT) I sometimes wish I could be more like her.
EXHALES ONE LAST TIME
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 113
(OBLIVIOUS) If she was here she’d be doing something useful. Not just prattling on, like a mouth on... [legs] (TRAILS OFF; REALISATION) Savinio? Savinio? — Oh, hell.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 114
SCENE 60. BOTANICAL GARDENS
SOUNDS OF DISTRESSED SHIP. SWIRLING WHIRLWIND OF VOICES
AS BEFORE, PLUS:
[FROM SCENE 23] I can feel it. Growing. Growing inside me.
[FROM SCENE 5] But that’s an extraordinary rate of growth. Almost impossible!
[FROM SCENE 56] You need to run. You get to get yourself as far away from me as possible.
[FROM SCENE 46] Found you. My God. Who are you?
[FROM SCENE 53] Hey! Get your hands off me!
Ready, Hargreaves?
Memory downloaded, sir. If you would be so kind as to remove my head. Just a twist anti-clockwise should do it.
CLICK
How’s that?
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: (IE, NOW A DISEMBODIED HEAD) Excellent, sir. Thank you.
Well, can’t have you forgetting me again, can we?
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]:
Absolutely not, sir. My cranial casing is constructed of tritanium alloy, which should help prevent the erasure of my hard drive. Fifteen seconds to event horizon.
And you’re going to — what? Just walk through the time rift? With that robot’s head tucked underneath your arm?
That’s the idea. Ready, Hargreaves?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 115
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: As I'll ever be, Sir.
Then here we go!!!
CHARGES INTO THE CACOPHONY OF VOICES.
No!!! Come back!!! Come back!!!
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 116
SCENE 61. CORRIDOR
RUNS TO STOP.
100 YDS DISTANT) (SCREAM OF PAIN
(BREATHING HARD) Poor woman.
(TRUNDLING UP) May I be of assistance, Madam?
(HUSHED) Shhhhh! — The Captain?
(LOUDLY) Ah, yes. The weed problem round here is most vexatious. I find a squirt of herbicide usually does the trick.
Never mind that now. — Which is the shortest route to the medical centre?
Down this corridor, Miss. Do you require medical attention?
Yes — yes, I do. And quickly. — That’s the way I came. Is there no other way?
Alas, not. Shall I escort you there?
100 YDS DISTANT) (ROAR OF PAIN
I don’t think it’s going to be as easy as that.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 117
SCENE 62. BOTANICAL GARDENS
CACOPHONY OF VOICES ABRUPTLY ENDS, AS THE DOCTOR IS EJECTED
Goodness. What an unpleasant way to travel. Hargreaves?
HARGREAVES THE SHIP’S COMPUTER AND HARGREAVES THE ROBOTIC
HARGREAVES/BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: Yes?
Yes, this could get confusing. Hargreaves — I mean you, head Hargreaves —
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: Yes, sir?
Could you bring your shipboard counterpart up to speed on who I am, who you are and why we’re here?
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: With pleasure, Sir. Sending memory files.
A BURST OF RAPID COMPUTER NOISE TO SIGNIFY THIS CONVERSATION. BEAT.
Well! What an extraordinary story!
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: Is it not!
And it explains so much. The dust!
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: Yes, and the vegetation!
Quite so. Oh, what a relief.
If you’ve quite finished — could one of you do a quick life scan, and tell me where Tegan is?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 118
Of course, Sir. (COGITATES BRIEFLY, THEN:) Miss Tegan is in the central elevator on this level. It can most easily be reached by access corridor beta fifteen.
The elevator? What’s she doing there?
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 119
SCENE 63. CORRIDOR
ROAR OF PLANT CREATURE THAT WAS MAYNARD.
How far to the sick bay, Hargreaves? From here, I mean?
Twenty-three minutes, Miss.
And that’s if we can get past Captain Maynard first.
Captain Maynard is not aboard this vessel.
That creature, then.
I fear the question is moot, Miss. Your infection is spreading by the minute. At such a rate of progression...
I know. — Then there’s only one thing to do. Before the infection spreads any further. Hargreaves, I need you to amputate my arm.
Goodness me, madam. What an extraordinary request.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 120
SCENE 64. CORRIDOR BETA FIFTEEN
THE DOCTOR STRIDES TO HALT.
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: This would be the elevator in question, sir.
Excellent.
BUTTON. DOORS SLIDE OPEN.
(INSIDE) Doctor!
Tegan! — Ah. Who’s that in there with you?
That was Lieutenant Savinio.
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: Oh dear. I’m sorry.
So am I. (BEAT) Doctor, it was the creature — the one that was hunting me before. It’s still around here somewhere.
Is it indeed? Then we need to find the TARDIS.
Suits me fine. Where is it?
What do you mean, where is it? It was brought here by the time storm, along with you and the creature.
No it wasn’t!
What...? (BEAT) Are you sure?
Of course I’m sure! It’s hard to miss.
I don’t understand. It was definitely taken by the ergostorm - (REALISATION) Of course! Stupid of me! The fail-safes will have kicked in.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 121
Failsafes?
The Time Anomaly Relocation Distributors! When the old girl detected the anomaly’s effects, she’d have automatically shifted herself forward in time, to prevent herself being lost in limbo.
How far?
Oh, only an hour or two.
So what do we do? Sit around and wait for it to turn up?
Well, we’ve no choice about the waiting, but the sitting around is optional. Personally I’d advise against it.
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: Indeed, Sir.
There’s Nyssa to think about, for one thing. We need to find a cure for her infection.
Okay. How?
You’re not going to like the answer. We need a cutting from the plant that infected Nyssa.
You mean we need to go back in there to get it? Into the botanical gardens?
Yes and no. Yes, we need to go back in there. No, not to find the same plant that infected Nyssa — as it’s most likely dead.
Then why are we going back in there?
Ah. Well, you’re definitely not going to like this bit.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 122
SCENE 65. CORRIDOR
CREATURE ROARING OFF.
Could you do it, Hargreaves? Amputate, I mean?
I am a gardening droid, Miss. I do not have the necessary tools.
You have a saw, don’t you?
Yes, Miss. But no anaesthetic. And no method of sterilisation. The procedure would be painful, and extremely dangerous.
Better that than... the alternative.
I fear it is too late for such a procedure to work, Miss. Removing your arm will not remove the infection.
So I’1l turn into one of those things anyway?
Yes, Miss.
And there’s nothing I can do.
You could halt the progress of the infection, Miss.
But how? (REALISATION) Like Akunin halted it in Maynard, by placing myself in cryo-sleep!
An admirable idea, Miss.
ROAR OF PLANT CREATURE, OFF.
We just need to get there...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 123
SCENE 66. BOTANICAL GARDENS
TEGAN AND THE DOCTOR WALK THROUGH UNDERGROWTH
Doctor, why are you carrying Hargreaves’ head around with you?
Because he’s absolutely indispensable. If a little cumbersome.
BUTLER HARGREAVES [HEAD]: My apologies, sir.
THE SHIP LURCHES. METAL INFRASTRUCTURE GROANING, UNDER PRESSURE
IMMENSE FORCES.
What was that? Another time storm?
I don’t think so. I have a feeling this is just an echo of what’s happening in the present. Kineto-temporal feedback — very nasty.
Certainly sounds it. What is happening in the present?
(EMERGING FROM UNDERGROWTH) The Aquitaine is flying into the heart of the black hole - at the behest of your friend here. Isn’t that right, Doctor?
Ah. There you are - like a bad penny.
Doctor Akunin, I presume?
And you must be Tegan.
(TO AKUNIN) So, you decided to jump in after us. — What do you want, Akunin?
Before he decided to send us all to our doom, the Doctor and I were having a most interesting discussion on medical ethics. Unfortunately it was left unfinished.
I don’t have time to chat now - sorry. I’m rather busy.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 124
Oh, I think you can find the time, don’t you?
HE PRODUCES A SPACE WEAPON — CHARGING UP FX?
Doctor, he’s got a gun!
Now will you talk?
There’s nothing to talk about. Your so-called Akunites are a biological blind-alley that should never have existed in the first place.
Oh, be careful, Doctor...
You won’t kill me. You need me to save your ship, and its iniquitous cargo.
Iniquitous? The Akunites? Who are you to judge them so?
WE HEAR THE DISTINCTIVE SHUFFLE OF AN APPROACHING PLANT
— SNIFFING THEM OUT
Judge for yourself...
An Akunite!
Keep well back, Doctor — those things are lethal.
THE CREATURE COMES CLOSER.
A fully-grown specimen — it’s beautiful!
It’s horrible.
I’m inclined to agree. Hardly the new evolutionary paradigm you promised, Akunin.
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 125
(APPROACHING CREATURE) Do you know who I am? (BEAT) I am your creator!
(SOTTO) Doctor, he’s flipped!
(SOTTO) Long ago, I’m afraid.
I nurtured you, I made you...!
How could you?! That thing might have been a friend of yours. — Or mine...
Tegan, I’m sure it’s not Nyssa.
You don’t know that!

Look at the scar tissue; the irregular formation of these appendicular nodes. This creature has had tissue samples taken from it, again and again. From what Akunin has told me, I’d say this was once Lieutenant Jennings.
He’s right! Freya! It is you..! — You understood why, didn’t you, Freya? We have a saying in Russia - Oo medalee dve storonee [oo med-ah-lee da-vear star-ranee] — ‘There are two
Sides to a medal.’ You understand now, yes? Your sacrifice wasn’t in vain.
FREYA/PLANT CREATURE: (HOARSELY — TRACE OF ORIGINAL VOICE) Akunin? Akunin!
(WARNING) Look out, it’s gonna strike!!!
ROARS AND DARTS OUT A TENDRIL, STABBING AKUNIN THROUGH THE HEART
Aaaaaargh!
That’s what happened to Savinio.
SLURPING SOUNDS
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 126
Urgh — now it’s feeding on him!
(DYING) Chto posyeyesh to I pozhnyosh... [sh-to pah-see-yesh toe ee pazh-nyosh...] (DIES)
HORRID SLURPING
‘As you sow, so shall you reap.’
Yes — well it could be us next. Come on, let’s go!
Take Hargreaves’ head, Tegan. (PASSES IT) There’s something I need to do, while it’s distracted. I’1ll be right behind you.
You promise?
Yes. Now - go!
RUNS OFF, AND THE DOCTOR SQUATS NEXT TO THE FEEDING
Now... gently does it...
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 127
SCENE 67. CORRIDOR
CREATURE GROWLING, PACING CORRIDOR.
(APPROACHING) Captain Maynard?
(BESIDE HER) Careful, Ma’am.
MAYNARD/PLANT CREATURE:
STOPS, SNIFFS, GROWLS
Do you remember me? Nyssa.
MAYNARD/PLANT CREATURE: Nysssss-ah.
Yes, Nyssa. I’m so sorry, for what Akunin did to you.
MAYNARD/PLANT CREATURE: Akunin... was.. right. Before... I was weak. But now... I am cured.
Stay back, Captain. I don’t want to hurt you...
MAYNARD/PLANT CREATURE: You? Hurt me? (THROATY CHUCKLE)
You’re not as strong as you think. Hargreaves? Are you ready?
Yes, Madam.
ATTACHMENT
MAYNARD/PLANT CREATURE: What issss that?
Weedkiller, ma’am. I’m afraid it may sting a little.
Now, Hargreaves!
SPRAYS MAYNARD WITH WEEDKILLER
MAYNARD/PLANT CREATURE: No! It burns! Arggghhhhhh!
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL)
Hurry, Hargreaves!
Yes, Miss.
THEY RUN/TRUNDLE AWAY
Page 128
by Simon Barnard & Paul Morris (FINAL) Page 129
SCENE 68. CORRIDOR BETA FOURTEEN
THE DOCTOR CATCHES UP WITH TEGAN
Doctor. Did you get it? The cutting?
I think so.
Good. One less thing to worry ab[out] -
A CRASH. THE SHIP SHAKES AND THE INFRASTRUCTURE GROANS AS BEFORE. THIS TIME IT DOESN’T ABATE, BUT CONTINUES FOR THE REST OF THE SCENE.
Woah. (BEAT) Is that your... whatever-it-was feedback, like before?
